summary: This document is a compilation of news clips from the Southern District of New York (SDNY) dated June 25, 2019. It covers various unrelated cases and matters, including the appointment of a new NYCHA chair, fraud cases, a kidnapping by an Uber driver, a wildlife trafficking arrest, and an update on the Jeffrey Epstein case where prosecutors argue his 2007 plea deal should stand.

persons.name: Gregory Russ
persons.role: Incoming Chairman and CEO of NYCHA
persons.context: Newly hired head of the New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA) with a $400,000+ salary, facing scrutiny over his experience and plans to use the RAD program.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Financier whose controversial 2007 plea deal is being challenged by victims; prosecutors argue the deal must stand.

persons.name: Byung "B.J." Pak
persons.context: Filed a motion arguing Epstein's non-prosecution agreement should not be invalidated and that victims' rights under the CVRA are limited.

persons.name: Alexander Acosta
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney (Miami), Secretary of Labor
persons.context: Former prosecutor who engineered the 2007 plea deal for Jeffrey Epstein; his handling of the case is under review.

persons.name: Kenneth Marra
persons.context: Judge presiding over the victims' challenge to Epstein's plea deal; previously ruled the deal violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: British socialite accused of recruiting women and underage girls for Epstein; has not been charged and denies allegations.

persons.name: Kenneth Starr
persons.context: One of Epstein's high-powered lawyers who pressured prosecutors for the 2007 plea deal.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: One of Epstein's high-powered lawyers who pressured prosecutors for the 2007 plea deal.

persons.name: Jack Scarola
persons.context: Attorney for Epstein's victims, arguing the plea deal was a conspiracy and should be invalidated.

persons.name: Harbir Parmar
persons.context: Sentenced to three years in prison for kidnapping a female passenger, changing her destination to Boston, and assaulting her.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Announced sentences in multiple unrelated cases covered in the clips, including the Parmar kidnapping and the Elizabeth Pierce fraud case.

persons.name: Elizabeth Ann Pierce
persons.role: Former FCC committee chair, convicted fraudster
persons.context: Former CEO of Quintillion sentenced to five years for defrauding investors using fake broadband contracts.

persons.name: Moazu Kromah
persons.context: Arrested in Uganda for trafficking rhino horn and elephant ivory valued at $7.4 million; extradited to the U.S.

persons.name: Stephen Calk
persons.context: Indicted for allegedly approving risky loans to Paul Manafort in exchange for help securing a Trump administration job.

persons.name: Paul Manafort
persons.context: Received loans from Stephen Calk's bank while Calk sought his help in obtaining a Trump administration position.

persons.name: Steven Henning
persons.context: Pleaded guilty to defrauding investors out of $2 million through a sham intellectual property company called OpportuniP.

persons.name: Paul Ceglia
persons.context: Charged with trying to defraud Mark Zuckerberg; became a fugitive and was released by Ecuador, denying U.S. extradition.

connections.description: Maxwell is accused of recruiting women and underage girls for Epstein's alleged sex trafficking operation.
As U.S. Attorney, Acosta negotiated the controversial non-prosecution plea deal for Epstein in 2007.
Starr was one of Epstein's lead defense attorneys who pressured prosecutors for the plea deal.
Dershowitz was one of Epstein's lead defense attorneys who pressured prosecutors for the plea deal.
Calk's bank approved $16 million in loans for Manafort while Calk sought Manafort's help in obtaining a Trump administration job.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein enters a secret plea deal with federal prosecutors, pleading guilty to state prostitution charges and avoiding federal sex-trafficking charges.

events.title: DOJ Motion to Uphold Epstein Deal
events.description: U.S. Attorney B.J. Pak files a motion arguing Epstein's 2007 plea deal must stand and that victims have no right to demand its invalidation or a new prosecution.

events.title: Uber Driver Kidnapping
events.description: Uber driver Harbir Parmar kidnaps a sleeping female passenger, changes her destination to Boston, assaults her, and leaves her on the side of I-95 in Connecticut.

events.title: Parmar Sentencing
events.description: Harbir Parmar is sentenced to three years in prison for kidnapping and wire fraud related to the Uber incident and overcharging customers.

events.title: Arrest of Wildlife Trafficker
events.description: Moazu Kromah, a key alleged ivory and rhino horn trafficker, is arrested in Uganda and quickly brought to a New York federal courthouse.

keyFacts: Federal prosecutors argue Jeffrey Epstein's 2007 plea deal cannot be invalidated and that victims have no right under the law to demand a new prosecution.
The Epstein plea deal, engineered by then-U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta, granted federal immunity to Epstein and unnamed others, and involved secret negotiations that kept victims in the dark.
At least two dozen underage girls were identified as victims of Epstein's alleged sex trafficking operation from 1998 to 2006.
The document is a news clipping summary showing the Southern District of New York's caseload on a single day, covering topics from public housing to fraud to the high-profile Epstein case.
In an unrelated matter, Uber driver Harbir Parmar was sentenced to three years for kidnapping and assaulting a passenger after changing her destination while she slept.
